#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Do Analogies
#Text=Analogies are an important part of writing and test-taking in many schools , but they can be a challenge to master .
#Text=When writing , analogies make comparisons between two concepts so that your reader can better understand something unfamiliar .
#Text=On tests , questions called verbal analogies test your reasoning by asking you to properly complete comparisons .
#Text=It might take some practice to understand analogies , but when you learn the concept and work on it a little every day , you can master them .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Solving Verbal Analogies on Tests
#Text=Learn the analogy symbols .
#Text=Before you can start solving verbal analogies on a test , you have to learn to read them .

#Text=The symbol “ : ” means “ is to ” while the “ : : ” symbol means “ as . ” So an analogy that reads “ doctor : hospital : : basketball player : arena ” actually means , “ doctor is to hospital as basketball player is to arena . ”
#Text=Master the common types of analogical relationships .
#Text=Analogies can come in almost any form , but on tests they often follow certain types of relationships .
#Text=Analogies are often on simple relationships like synonyms , antonyms , parts to a whole , or actions to a result .
#Text=They may also include :
#Text=Uses , such as cup is to drink .
#Text=Users , such as contractor is to hammer .
#Text=Places , such as Santiago is to Chile .
#Text=Product to producer , such as wool is to sheep .
#Text=Degree of intensity , such as warm is to scalding .
#Text=Establish the type of relationship .
#Text=Reading an analogy is just the beginning .
#Text=The analogy setup tells you that the relationship between the two parts of the analogy is the same .
#Text=To properly complete an analogy , you need to determine the nature of the relationship provided by the test question .
#Text=If you have an analogy saying , “ water : glass : : cereal : _____ , ” then you need to think about how the water and glass relate to each other .
#Text=Water goes in a glass , so the proper choice for the cereal would be “ bowl ” as opposed to choices like “ plate ” or “ spoon . ”
#Text=Take your time .
#Text=Analogies may come up on timed tests , which can make them extra stressful .
#Text=Good time management is required for any test , but it can actually hurt you to rush through a section .
#Text=Instead of rushing through as fast as you can , allot a designated amount of time to answer each question .
#Text=If you ca n’t answer it in your time frame , then move on .
#Text=If you have 30 minutes to complete 50 analogies , for example , you could allow 30 seconds for each question .
#Text=This gives you time to consider each question , as well as a buffer to go back and answer questions you skipped earlier .
#Text=Using Analogies in Your Writing
#Text=Learn to distinguish metaphors , similes , and analogies .
#Text=These three rhetorical devices are similar , but they are n’t exactly the same .
#Text=A metaphor makes a direct comparison to establish a new meaning .
#Text=A simile makes a simple comparison using “ like ” or “ as . ”
#Text=An analogy also compares , but typically makes a more complex argument by focusing on relationships .
#Text=“ Her smile was a ray of sunshine , ” would be a metaphor .
#Text=“ Her smile was as bright as a beam of sun , ” would be a simile .
#Text=An analogy would make more particular comparisons between a smile and the sun . “
#Text=The warmth and intensity of her smile was as bright as a beam of light , ” makes multiple , direct connections between the smile and light .
#Text=“ That meeting was a rollercoaster , ” is a metaphor .
#Text=“ That meeting was like a rollercoaster , ” is a simile .
#Text=“ That meeting was a rollercoaster ride of emotions , ” is an example of an analogy .
#Text=Determine if your comparison needs an analogy .
#Text=Not every type of comparison needs an analogy .
#Text=Metaphors and similes work better for simple comparisons .
#Text=Think about what you want to compare .
#Text=Analogies work best for concepts rather than individual subjects such as a person or object .
#Text=Comparing the color of a blue shirt to the color of the sky , for example , would best be done with a simile or metaphor .
#Text=Comparing the movement of electricity through wires to the flow of water through pipes , however , should be done with an analogy .
#Text=Make a direct connection .
#Text=Analogies do not need to be long or fancy .
#Text=Their purpose is to make a concept easier to understand .
#Text=Start your analogy by making a direct comparison between your two subjects .
#Text=Then , you can point out how your subjects are similar .
#Text=When describing an okapi , for example , it is easiest to say , " This animal looks like a short-necked giraffe with zebra striping on its legs and brown fur on its body . "
#Text=This draws on what your reader already knows about zebras and giraffes to help them visualize the animal .
#Text=Avoid over-comparing .
#Text=Your analogy should do most of the comparing for you .
#Text=Gently point out how your concepts are similar .
#Text=Resist the urge to make a detailed comparison .
#Text=After all , the whole point of your analogy is to avoid going into complex detail .
#Text=With the water and electricity example , the comparison would be that electricity flows through wires like water through pipes .
#Text=You do not need to explain how electric currents are generated to get your point across .
#Text=Working on Analogies at Home
#Text=Take a practice test for verbal analogies .
#Text=If you are working on verbal analogies , take a few practice tests before you take your real test .
#Text=These will help you get a better idea of the types of analogies that will be on your test .
#Text=It will also help you practice good time management .
#Text=Make sure to take a practice test similar to the test you will take .
#Text=An ACT prep test wo n’t help you much if you are getting ready for the GRE .
#Text=There are a number of practice tests available for free online for a broad range of tests .
#Text=Take a few tests from a few sources to get more practice .
#Text=Write your own prompts .
#Text=Help build your analogy writing skills by creating a list of prompts .
#Text=Then , take two to three minutes each day to respond to one of your prompts .
#Text=Some potential analogical prompts could include :
#Text=What if feels like getting out of bed .
#Text=How you feel taking a difficult test .
#Text=What it ’s like to finish a good book .
#Text=How you go about trying to make new friends .
#Text=How to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich .
#Text=Try your analogies on a friend .
#Text=Once you have developed a few good analogies , read them out to a friend and ask for feedback .
#Text=Have them tell you if your analogies make sense .
#Text=If they do n’t , ask them what is unclear and use their feedback to revise them .
